page.title: 07BUILDING CONSTRUCTION
page.content: THE HOUSES NEAR THE MENDIP HILLS ARE BUILT MOSTLY FROM{LIMESTONE.}THIS HAS BEEN QUARRIED FROM THE HILLS FOR MANY YEARS. LIMESTONE IS STILL QUARRIED ALTHOUGH NOT AS MUCH AS IT USED TO BE.THE HOUSES ARE MOSTLY COVERED WITH RED TILES ALTHOUGH A FEW ARE TILED WITH SLATE WHICH WAS MINED IN{DORSET. THE MAJORITY OF THE HOUSES WERE BUILT IN THE{VICTORIAN}ERA.IN THE BIGGER VILLAGES SOME OF THE HOUSES ARE MADE FROM RED BRICKS AND THEN UPDATED WITH RENDERING .ONE OR TWO HOUSES SITUATED IN THE MENDIP WOODS ARE CONSTRUCTED ALMOST ENTIRELY FROM WOOD. THE WALLS OF HOUSES IN THIS AREA VARY IN THICKNESS FROM 0.15 METRES UP TO 1 METRE. A FEW OF THE OLDER HOUSES HAVE BLACK STAINED BEAMS USED IN THEIR CONSTRUCTION. AS WELL AS HOLDING THE ROOF UP THEY ARE A STRIKING FEATURE.
